resources.name: soil_data

fields.name: plot
fields.title: Plot
fields.description: Plot number.  1-32 at Rothamsted, 33-64 at Woburn

fields.name: block
fields.title: Block
fields.description: Block number 1 or 2. Two replicates within randomised blocks.

fields.name: sub-plot
fields.title: Sub-plot
fields.description: All plots divided into two sub-plots, 1 and 2,  in 1974-1980 to test Mg,  to test Mn (1987-1990) and S (1991-1996). There are no sub-plots in the other years.

fields.name: sample_year
fields.title: Year in which soil sampled
fields.description: Year when soil sampled.

fields.name: sample_date
fields.title: Date when soil sampled
fields.description: Date when soil sampled. Not sampled every year. Baseline soil sampled in February 1962, prior to treatments. Soil samples were generally taken in the autumn, after the current crop was harvested and before the soil was ploughed for the next harvest year, so that the soil properties could be related to the treatments applied in that harvest year.

fields.name: plough_date
fields.title: Date when soil ploughed
fields.description: Date when soil ploughed, usually in the autumn after soil samples taken.

fields.name: soil_depth
fields.title: Depth of soil sampled
fields.description: Depth of soil sampled; in some years more than one depth. For topsoil, 12-20 cores were taken from the central section of each plot and combined to make one sample, generally 5-6 cores were taken for subsoil. If sample depth not recorded, assumed to be 0-23cm.

fields.name: crop
fields.title: Crop type grown
fields.description: Name of crop grown before soil sampled

fields.name: lime_date
fields.title: Date lime applied
fields.description: Date lime applied. Not applied every year.

fields.name: liming_factor_level
fields.title: Lime treatment
fields.description: The four different lime treatments.

fields.name: annual_lime
fields.title: Annual lime application in this year
fields.description: Actual amount of lime applied in this year. Applied four or six times between March 1962- November 1986

fields.name: cumulative_lime
fields.title: Total cumulative lime application by this year
fields.description: Cumulative sum of total amount of lime applied up to the current year.

fields.name: p_factor_level
fields.title: P treatment between 1962 and 1980, and 1981-1996
fields.description: The different phosphorus treatments applied 1962-1980, and 1981-1996

fields.name: k_1962-80_factor_level
fields.title: K treatment between 1962 and 1980
fields.description: Whether potassium treatment is applied or not, 1962-1980

fields.name: mg_1974-78_factor_level
fields.title: Mg treatment between 1974 and 1978
fields.description: Whether magnesium treatment is applied or not, 1974-1978

fields.name: mn_1987-90_factor_level
fields.title: Mn treatment between 1987 and 1990
fields.description: Whether foliar manganese treatment is applied or not, 1987-1990

fields.name: s_1991-96_factor_level
fields.title: S treatment between 1991 and 1996
fields.description: Whether sulfur treatment is applied or not, 1991-1996

fields.name: soil_pH
fields.title: Soil pH
fields.description: Soil pH in water; 1:2.5 soil: water suspension using a standard electrode and pH meter.

fields.name: olsen_p
fields.title: Olsen P (plant available soil P)
fields.description: Soil extracted with a solution of 0.5 M NaHCO3, buffered at pH 8.5, after the method of Olsen et al, 1954.

fields.name: exch_ca
fields.title: Exchangeable soil calcium
fields.description: Exchangeable soil calcium. Measured in sieved (<2mm) air-dry soil leached with 1 M ammonium acetate, adjusted to pH 7. Leachates analysed by emission or atomic absorption flame spectrophotometry.  Since 1989, the extracts have been analysed by ICP-OES (Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectrometer).

fields.name: exch_k
fields.title: Exchangeable soil potassium
fields.description: Exchangeable soil potassium. Measured in sieved (<2mm) air-dry soil leached with 1 M ammonium acetate, adjusted to pH 7. Leachates analysed by emission or atomic absorption flame spectrophotometry.  Since 1989, the extracts have been analysed by ICP-OES (Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectrometer). In 1994 an unusually high blank (17.5), this has not been subtracted.

fields.name: exch_mg
fields.title: Exchangeable soil magnesium
fields.description: Exchangeable soil magnesium. Measured in sieved (<2mm) air-dry soil leached with 1 M ammonium acetate, adjusted to pH 7. Leachates analysed by emission or atomic absorption flame spectrophotometry.  Since 1989, the extracts have been analysed by ICP-OES (Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectrometer).

fields.name: exch_na
fields.title: Exchangeable soil sodium
fields.description: Exchangeable soil sodium. Measured in sieved (<2mm) air-dry soil leached with 1 M ammonium acetate, adjusted to pH 7. Leachates analysed by emission or atomic absorption flame spectrophotometry.  Since 1989, the extracts have been analysed by ICP-OES (Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectrometer).

fields.name: exch_mn
fields.title: Exchangeable soil manganese
fields.description: Exchangeable soil managnese. Measured in sieved (<2mm) air-dry soil leached with 1 M ammonium acetate, adjusted to pH 7. Leachates analysed by emission or atomic absorption flame spectrophotometry.  Since 1989, the extracts have been analysed by ICP-OES (Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectrometer).

fields.name: note_id
fields.title: Note
fields.description: Whether notes are applied or not

resources.title: Soil data
resources.description: The main data table containing soil chemical data for all plots and all treatments, 1962-1996. Includes soil pH, Olsen P and exchangeable Ca, K, Mg, Na and Mn (ammonium acetate method). Soil not measured every year, last sample taken in 1994. Baseline soil pH measurements taken in March 1962, before lime treatments applied. Soil samples were generally taken in the autumn, after the current crop was harvested and before the soil was ploughed for the next harvest year, so that the soil properties could be related to the treatments applied in the previous harvest year.  The soil was analysed shortly after sampling. Also includes lime (chalk) and fertilizer treatments. Updated January 2024 with revisions to Olsen P data in 1972 and 1982 (see notes_data).

name: woburn-long-term-liming-experiment-soil-chemical-properties-1962-1996
title: Woburn long-term liming experiment soil chemical properties 1962-1996
description:
### Abstract
The experiment tests the effects of different amounts of lime (and thus soil pH), P and K on a sequence of arable crops, on a sandy soil at Woburn Experimental Farm, from 1962-1996. Mg, Mn and S were tested on split plots at different times. Target soil pH was 4.5, 5.5, 6.5 and 7.5. This dataset contains soil pH, Olsen P and exchangeable cations (Ca, K, Mg and Na, ammonium acetate method) on soil sampled several times between 1962 and 1996.  There was also a baseline sampling before the experiment was established. There is a parallel experiment at Rothamsted Experimental Farm. This experiment was discontinued in 1997.  **This dataset was updated January 2nd 2024, see technical information**  

This dataset was partially funded by the BBSRC Institute Strategic Programme Soil to Nutrition (BBS/E/C/000I0310).
### Methods
Period 1 (1962-1980): four lime levels with and without fertilizer P and K. Magnesium was tested on split plots 1974-1978. Period 2 (1981-1996): four lime levels with four P levels. Manganese was tested on split plots 1987-1990; Sulphur was tested on split plots 1991-1996. There are two replicates. 

- **Soil pH** measured in water: 1:2.5 soil: water suspension using a standard electrode and pH meter.
- **Olsen P** (plant-available soil P) soil extracted with a solution of 0.5 M NaHCO<sub>3</sub>, buffered at pH8.5, after the method of Olsen et al, 1954. Shown as mg PO<sub>4</sub>-P/kg dry soil. 
- **Exchangeable cations** measured in sieved (<2mm) air-dry soil leached with 1 M ammonium acetate, adjusted to pH 7. Leachates analysed by emission or atomic absorption flame spectrophotometry.  Since 1989, the extracts have been analysed by ICP-OES (Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectrometer).
### Technical Info
Air-dried soil, sieved (<2mm). Topsoil (usually 0-23cm) and some sub-soil measurements. For topsoil 12-20 cores were taken from the central area of each plot and combined to make one sample. For subsoil, generally 5-6 cores were taken and combined. Baseline soil pH measurements were taken in February 1962, before the first lime application. Soil samples were generally taken in the autumn, after the current crop was harvested and before the soil was ploughed for the next harvest year, so that the soil properties could be related to the treatments applied in the previous harvest year. The soil was analysed shortly after sampling.  

Olsen P data for 1982 removed in this version, as the data is unreliable. Olsen P data for plot 50, 1972 removed as this plot was not sampled in 1972 and it was shown in error in V1.
### Other
- **Olsen et al, 1954**   Olsen S.R., Cole C.V., Watanabe F.S., Dean L.A. (1954) Estimation of available phosphorus in soils by extraction with sodium bicarbonate. USDA Circular 939, US Gov. Print. Office, Washington, D.C.
### Provenance
Information is taken from original raw data sheets and analysis files, held in the archives at Rothamsted Research. The data is derived from measurements made by the Analytical Chemistry Unit, Rothamsted Research, Harpenden.
### Quality
In accordance with the Joint Code of Practice for Research at Rothamsted, data processing in e-RA follow rigorous standard operating procedures to ensure the quality and correctness of data collected in the field through to depositing in the e-RA database. To ensure quality control during data inputting, the data sets were typed on two separate occasions (double data entry). During the second typing (verification) the data values were compared with those typed on the earlier occasion, and any discrepancies were resolved before verification continued. This procedure also set out how to handle situations where the written records were illegible or ambiguous. This procedure avoided visual checking of data, which can be very inaccurate.
The Analytical Chemistry Unit follows the Joint Code of Practice (JCoPR) and participates in European Quality Assurance programmes. All performance is strictly monitored using certified external standards alongside in-house standard materials. Standards and check samples are monitored and recorded.
